subject: Re: [junit] Re: Running JUnit Test Cases from Web Browser
msgSnippet: if you are just running a regular servlet you can communicate the progress to the response by flushing it every now and then... ...
messageBody:
if you are just running a regular servlet you can
communicate the progress to the response by flushing
it every now and then...


--- Mike Clark <mike@...> wrote:
> Jason Rogers wrote:
>
> > --- sramaswa007@... wrote:
> > > Hi Jason,
> > >
> > > Thanks for the reply. Yes looks like I need
> to have a servlet that
> > > can reload every 5 sec. Assuming that I have
> such a servlet, what do
> > > I need to do to capture the results at some
> instance. Right now I am
> > > using TestResult class to store the results and
> then passing them as
> > > response to the browser after all the test cases
> are run. But in
> > > this case do I need to use TestListener
> interface and then use the
> > > addListener method of TestResult class. Please
> let me know.
> >
> > That's a viable solution, probably not the only
> one though.
> >
>
> Have you tried JUnitServlet?
>
> http://c2.com/cgi-bin/wiki?JunitServlet
>
> It claims that the HTML result page updates itself
> when the tests are finished. I haven't tried it
> myself, but it looks like another possible solution.
>
> Mike
